newsitem.title: NORWAY: Norway May oil output dips 5 pct to 3.11 mln bpd.
newsitem.headline: Norway May oil output dips 5 pct to 3.11 mln bpd.

text.p: Norwegian crude output slipped five percent in May from April due to a series of planned and unscheduled shutdowns, a Reuters survey of oil companies operating in Norwegian waters showed.
Norway pumped an average 3.11 million barrels per day (bpd) last month compared with 3.28 million bpd in April.
The figure does not include 166,761 bpd of condensate production from the North Sea Sleipner East and West developments.
One notable slippage in production was at Norske Shell's Draugen platform in the Norwegian Sea, which was closed for eight days scheduled maintenance, a Shell spokesman said.
Draugen throughput fell 27 percent to 133.122 bpd in May from more than 180,000 bpd a month earlier.

The North Sea Vigdis oilfield, which came on stream in January five months ahead of schedule, produced an average 371 bpd in May after a series of unplanned shutdowns due to problems with the gas compressor.

Vigdis produced for just eight days between May 16 and May 23. Operator Saga Petroleum ASA attributed the problems to a design fault in the compressor and said it planned to bring the field back on stream at the end of June.
Vigdis output was around 50,000 bpd before the latest incident, but peak output is forecast to reach around 75,000 bpd.
Production at Saga's Snorre field was off almost 10 percent due to work on wells.
"We can only produce what the wells will produce at the moment so we have more capacity on the platform than we can use," a spokesman for the company said.
"But we have almost completed another well, which took a little longer than thought, so we should be back to normal soon."
State operator Den norske stats oljeselskap AS said it had shut down its Veslefrikk oilfield on June 9 for scheduled turnaround. The field is due to be down until June 21.
